overview: From 2025-12-14 to 2025-12-21, ethereum-optimism/optimism had 25 new PRs (12 merged), 12 new issues, and 46 active contributors.

topIssues.title: SPIKE: Rework Proofs Action Testing to Support Supernodes
topIssues.author: Inphi
topIssues.body:
Currently, our action testing approach may not be fully compatible with the Supernode architecture. Since virtual nodes (VNs) inside Chain Containers are already op-nodes, we have an opportunity to simplify the proofs (action) test migration for the Supernode by exposing the action test pattern directly from these virtual nodes.

The Supernode shouldn't need to actively drive virtual nodes except in specific cases (e.g., triggering reorgs induced by the Validation activity). We want to control local derivation more directly through the virtual nodes themselves. This suggests we can replicate existing proofs action test scenarios without directly interacting with the Supernode.
It would be a big win if we can pull this off as the current supervisor-based action control is too intrusive and requires maintenance against changes to its internals.

The goal of this spike is to determine whether this approach is viable, and if not, consider an alternative approach.
We should be able to answer the following questions:

1. **Direct VN Control**: Can we expose and execute action test patterns directly from virtual nodes within Chain Containers?
2. **Supernode Decoupling**: Can we run proof-focused action tests without requiring Supernode interaction for most scenarios?
3. **Test Scenario Replication**: Can we replicate existing action test scenarios?

Let's timebox this to 3 days.

topIssues.title: Run precompile FP tests on Jovian fork
topIssues.author: Inphi

topIssues.title: Document cannonKonaPrestate requirement for upgrades
topIssues.author: Inphi
topIssues.body:
While `opcm.upgrade` does not enforce that the cannon-kona prestate is empty, standard chains should always set the cannon-kona prestate. 
Let's find a suitable location to document this requirement for standard chains. Perhaps it could be defined in https://specs.optimism.io/protocol/configurability.html.

topIssues.author: pauldowman

topPRs.title: Feat/pipeline metrics
topPRs.author: saintparish4
topPRs.body:
# Add Derivation Pipeline Stage Metrics

## Summary
Adds comprehensive timing, queue depth, and throughput metrics to all derivation pipeline stages for performance monitoring and bottleneck identification.

## Motivation
Addresses limited observability in the derivation pipeline. Related to issues #9347 (L1 RPC bottlenecks), #9992, #10638 (derivation errors).

## Changes
- Added `DerivationMetrics` interface and Prometheus implementation
- Instrumented all 7 pipeline stages (L1Traversal → EngineQueue)
- Added 7 metric types covering processing time, queue depth, throughput
- Included tests (100% coverage) and benchmarks (<0.1% overhead)
- Created Grafana dashboard

## Testing
- Unit tests: ✅ Passing

## Breaking Changes
None - purely additive

## Review Guide
1. Interface: `op-node/rollup/derive/metrics.go`
2. Tests: `op-node/rollup/driver/metrics_derivation_test.go`  
3. Example instrumentation: Check any modified stage file

Ready for feedback!

topPRs.title: WIP: Add environment for containerizing hash-locked Mise flows
topPRs.author: RyanSquared
topPRs.body:
<!--
Contributions welcome! See https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/.github/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

**Description**

This enables a hash-locked Mise flow, where running `make shell` builds a container, verifies the contents with separate lockfiles, and mounts the current working directory into a shell with `mise` and `pip` installed programs in `$PATH`.

Note: I did have to install some programs separately using `pip`, as there was no way to install them using `mise` where I could control the exact versions installed. Every other program should be hash-locked without issue.

**Tests**

Please describe any tests you've added. If you've added no tests, or left important behavior untested, please explain why not.
-->

<!--
Add any other context about the problem you're solving.
-->

topPRs.title: feat: add SuperFaultDisputeGameV2
topPRs.author: maurelian
topPRs.body:
## Summary

Implements SuperFaultDisputeGameV2 following the V2 architecture pattern established in PR #16929.

## Key Changes

### New Files
- **`src/dispute/v2/SuperFaultDisputeGameV2.sol`**: V2 implementation with CWIA helper functions
- **`interfaces/dispute/v2/ISuperFaultDisputeGameV2.sol`**: Interface for SuperFaultDisputeGameV2

### Modified Files
- **`src/libraries/DevFeatures.sol`**: Added `DEPLOY_V2_SUPER_DISPUTE_GAMES` feature flag
- **`test/dispute/SuperFaultDisputeGame.t.sol`**: Added `SuperFaultDisputeGameV2_Constructor_Test` with constructor validation and CWIA tests
- **`test/dispute/DisputeGameFactory.t.sol`**: Added `setupSuperFaultDisputeGameV2()` factory helpers

### Implementation Details

The V2 implementation follows the same CWIA (Clones With Immutable Arguments) pattern as FaultDisputeGameV2:
- Added `expectedInitCallDataLength()` helper returning `6 + immutableArgsByteCount()`
- Added `immutableArgsByteCount()` helper returning `244` (total CWIA bytes)
- Updated version from `0.6.0` to `0.7.0`
- All CWIA offsets remain unchanged (SuperFaultDisputeGame was already V2-compatible)
- Preserves all Super-specific features:
  - `l2SequenceNumber()` instead of `l2BlockNumber()`
  - `startingProposal()` instead of `startingOutputRoot()`
  - No `challengeRootL2Block()` function
  - Validates `l2ChainId` is zero in `initialize()`

### Testing

Added comprehensive tests following the FaultDisputeGameV2 pattern:
- Constructor parameter validation (max depth, split depth, clock extension)
- CWIA validation tests (extra/missing immutable args bytes)
- All tests feature-gated with `DEPLOY_V2_SUPER_DISPUTE_GAMES` flag

### Pre-PR Checks

All checks passing:
- ✓ Build successful
- ✓ All tests compile
- ✓ Interface validation
- ✓ Semver checks
- ✓ Code quality checks

## Test Plan

```bash
# Run V2 tests with feature flag enabled
DEV_FEATURE__DEPLOY_V2_SUPER_DISPUTE_GAMES=true forge test --match-contract SuperFaultDisputeGameV2
```

## Related

- Follows pattern from PR #16929 (FaultDisputeGame → FaultDisputeGameV2)
- Part of the broader V2 dispute game architecture

topPRs.title: proofs: Add provable output roots to super DGs
topPRs.author: Inphi
topPRs.body:
This patch updates the `SuperFaultDisputeGame` to be explicit about proving all output roots in the super root. This is accomplished by requiring proposers to provide the preimage of the super root when creating a `SuperFaultDisputeGame`.

The Super DG is then extended with a `rootClaim(uint256 _l2ChainId)` method that returns specific output roots contained in the proposal. This allows withdrawals to be proven using only an output root.

fixes https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/18521, https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/18518

topContributors.summary: Inphi: Focused on the proof system in `ethereum-optimism/optimism`, advancing a feature to add provable output roots in an open pull request (#18605) that included the bulk of their code changes (+842/-164 lines). They also merged a dependency update (PR #18611), provided 3 code reviews, and created issues to track future work on precompile tests and withdrawal scripts (#17348, #18615). This work primarily involved modifications to tests, code, and configuration files.
sbvegan: Supported team progress this week through code review, approving 2 pull requests. They also committed minor changes related to bugfixes and other work.

ajsutton focused on testing infrastructure this week, merging a pull request to enable jovian for proofs precompile tests in `ethereum-optimism/optimism` (#18606). In addition to this change, they were active in project discussions, commenting on three issues and providing one review. This activity reflects a primary focus on test-related work.
smartcontracts: No activity this week.

pauldowman: Contributed to the Ethereum Optimism ecosystem by updating the Superchain registry with a new Kona version in PR ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry#1184. They also proactively identified areas for improvement by opening two issues in the core Optimism repository related to testing and client libraries (#18613, #18614). Additionally, pauldowman supported the team by conducting two code reviews.

AmadiMichael: Engaged primarily in code review this week, providing comments on 7 pull requests. They also contributed a minor bugfix in a single commit (+1/-2 lines). This activity indicates a focus on bugfix work.
nonsense: No activity this week.
its-everdred: No activity this week.

maurelian: Made significant progress on unsubmitted work this week, with 20 commits resulting in over 950 new lines of code across 43 files. They also provided feedback on one pull request via a review comment. This development was primarily focused on bug fixes and other work.

janjakubnanista: Focused on improving core utilities in the ethereum-optimism/optimism repository, merging PR #18610 to add a new SafeRename ioutil utility. This contribution, categorized primarily as bugfix work, demonstrates a focus on enhancing the codebase.

karlfloersch: Focused on new feature development by opening a pull request to implement core filtering logic in `ethereum-optimism/optimism` (#18604). They also contributed to code quality by reviewing another pull request, where they requested changes.

atenalt: This week, atenalt's work centered on network configuration, where they activated the Fjord, Granite, and Holocene hardforks for the Cyber and Funki mainnets. This was accomplished through two merged pull requests (#1183, #1182) in the `ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry`.

pcw109550: Focused on bug fixes this week, authoring a substantial commit that modified 26 files (+688/-339 lines). In addition to this work, they also engaged in peer review, providing 5 comments on pull requests.
almanax-ai: Contributed to code quality by reviewing pull requests, leaving 6 comments to provide feedback.

stevennevins: Focused on local development this week, making 43 commits primarily related to bugfixes that modified 228 files (+2432/-1155 lines). While no pull requests were merged, they contributed to code review by commenting on 2 pull requests.

devin-ai-integration: Focused on improving contract test coverage in the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. They opened a pull request to enhance the AdminFaucetAuthModule tests (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18609).

ccerv1: Focused on expanding data export capabilities in the `op-analytics` repository by opening a pull request to add CSV dumps for Retroactive Funding Seasons 7-8 (ethereum-optimism/op-analytics#1774). This new feature work introduced a substantial change, adding over 5,300 lines of code and documentation.

lyh169: Focused on identifying and reporting issues this week, opening a new issue in the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository (#18608) to flag a potential nil pointer dereference in the `op-challenger`. They also contributed to discussions by commenting on two issues.
